choices.text: It will contain an oncogenic mutation
It will contain nested genes for antibiotic resistance
It will have lost some coding regions

questions.text: During a biochemistry lecture, professor teaches that pseudogenes are homologues of functional genes that lack promoters and are therefore part of the unexpressed DNA. It is thought that at least some of these pseudogenes were produced by reverse transcription of mRNA and insertion of the resultant cDNA into a chromosome by a virus. In addition to lacking a promoter and other regulatory elements, a pseudogene produced in this manner will also differ from the authentic gene in which one of the following ways?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It will lack introns Pseudogenes produced by reverse transcription of mRNA typically lack introns. This is because the process of reverse transcription generates a complementary DNA (cDNA) copy of the mRNA, which is a mature form of the gene without any introns. When the resulting cDNA is inserted back into the genome, it will not contain the introns that are present in the genomic DNA of the functional gene. This is a key distinction between functional genes and pseudogenes, as pseudogenes are generally considered non-functional due to their lack of regulatory elements (like promoters) and inability to produce the corresponding protein. Therefore, lack of introns is a primary characteristic of pseudogenes generated by reverse transcription. Incorrect Answers: A. It will contain an oncogenic mutation While it is possible for mutations to arise during the reverse transcription process or subsequent insertion into the genome, the primary feature of a pseudogene produced in this manner is its lack of introns and functional regulatory elements. Oncogenic mutations are not a defining feature of pseudogenes. The absence of a promoter and the inability to express the gene are more critical in defining pseudogenes. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. It will contain nested genes for antibiotic resistance Nested genes, which are genes that exist within the coding sequence of another gene, are not a feature of pseudogenes produced by reverse transcription. While nested genes can be present in genomes, they are not a consequence of the reverse transcription process that creates pseudogenes. Thus, this answer is not correct. C. It will have lost some coding regions While pseudogenes may have various mutations that could lead to the loss of some coding regions, the defining feature of pseudogenes generated by reverse transcription is the lack of introns, not necessarily the loss of coding regions. The cDNA copy of the mRNA can still be a full-length copy of the coding sequence, but it will be devoid of introns. Therefore, this option is less relevant than option D.

choices.text: Cytosine and uracil differ by one ribose sugar
The information from DNA is copied in the form of tRNA
Each nucleotide pair included two purines
The nucleotide of one strand from bonds with nucleotide of opposite strand

questions.text: Which of the following is true for DNA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. The nucleotide of one strand forms bonds with a nucleotide of the opposite strand." This is describing the base pairing that occurs in the double-stranded structure of DNA. In DNA, nitrogenous bases on one strand form hydrogen bonds with complementary bases on the opposite strand: adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). This complementary base pairing is critical for the double helix structure and for DNA replication. Incorrect Options: A. Cytosine and uracil differ by one ribose sugar: This is incorrect because cytosine and uracil are both pyrimidines, but they differ by a functional group, not a sugar. Cytosine contains an amino group (-NH2) at the 4-position, while uracil has a carbonyl group (=O) at the same position. Both cytosine (found in DNA) and uracil (found in RNA) are nucleobases, but they do not differ by a sugar. Additionally, the ribose sugar is found in RNA, and DNA contains deoxyribose sugar. B. The information from DNA is copied in the form of tRNA: This statement is incorrect because the information from DNA is first transcribed into mRNA (messenger RNA), not tRNA. The mRNA carries the genetic code from the DNA to the ribosome for protein synthesis. tRNA (transfer RNA) plays a role in translating the mRNA codons into amino acids during translation, but it is not directly involved in copying the information from DNA. C. Each nucleotide pair includes two purines: This statement is incorrect because in DNA, each nucleotide pair consists of one purine and one pyrimidine. Purines (adenine and guanine) pair with pyrimidines (thymine and cytosine) according to the base-pairing rules. For example, adenine (a purine) pairs with thymine (a pyrimidine), and guanine (a purine) pairs with cytosine (a pyrimidine).

questions.text: A nucleic acid was analyzed and found to contain 32% adenine, 18% guanine, 17% cytosine and 33% thymine. The nucleic acid must be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Double stranded DNA. In double-stranded DNA, the base pairing follows Chargaff's rule, where adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and guanine (G) pairs with cytosine (C) in roughly equal proportions. The given nucleic acid has 32% adenine (A) and 33% thymine (T), which are very close in percentage, showing that these two bases are paired. Similarly, the percentages of guanine (18%) and cytosine (17%) are also very close, indicating base pairing between these two as well. These base pairings and the near equality in their respective percentages strongly suggest a double-stranded DNA structure. A. Single stranded RNA is incorrect because in RNA, uracil (U) pairs with adenine (A), not thymine. In addition, the base composition in single-stranded RNA would not follow the same percentage relationships as seen in double-stranded DNA, especially since thymine is not present in RNA. The presence of thymine and the near-equal distribution of adenine and thymine rule out this option. B. Single stranded DNA is incorrect because single-stranded DNA does not follow the same base pairing rules as double-stranded DNA. While adenine and thymine should still be in close proximity in terms of percentage, the base composition would not show such a direct complementarity without the other strand to base-pair with, as seen in double-stranded DNA. C. Double stranded RNA is incorrect because RNA is typically single-stranded, and even in rare cases where RNA is double-stranded, it still follows the A-U and G-C base-pairing rules. The presence of thymine (T), which is absent in RNA, makes this option incorrect. Additionally, the percentages of bases in double-stranded RNA would be unlikely to match these proportions.

questions.text: If content of A is 15%, what is the amount of G in DNA according to Chargaff’s rule
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 35%. According to Chargaff's rule, in double-stranded DNA, the amount of adenine (A) is equal to thymine (T), and the amount of guanine (G) is equal to cytosine (C). If the content of adenine (A) is 15%, then thymine (T) must also be 15%. This means that the remaining 70% of the DNA must be composed of guanine (G) and cytosine (C) in equal amounts, meaning each must be 35%. Therefore, the amount of guanine (G) in this DNA is 35%. A. 15% is incorrect because if guanine were 15%, it would not follow Chargaff's rule, which requires the amount of guanine to be equal to the amount of cytosine, and the sum of adenine and thymine must match the sum of guanine and cytosine. C. 70% is incorrect because this value would imply that guanine makes up 70% of the total, which would be inconsistent with the base pairing rules of DNA. Given the fixed amount of adenine (15%), thymine (15%), and the need for an equal amount of guanine and cytosine, 70% would exceed the available space in the total 100%. D. 85% is also incorrect because if guanine were 85%, it would make up the vast majority of the DNA, leaving only a very small percentage for adenine, thymine, and cytosine. This would violate the requirement for balanced base pairing in double-stranded DNA.

questions.text: What is true for Watson and Crick base pairing rule
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A → T, C → G. Watson and Crick's base pairing rule states that in double-stranded DNA, adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). This is due to complementary hydrogen bonding between the nitrogenous bases: two hydrogen bonds form between adenine and thymine, and three hydrogen bonds form between cytosine and guanine. This pairing ensures the stability and proper structure of the DNA double helix. B. A → G, T → U is incorrect because adenine does not pair with guanine in DNA, and thymine does not pair with uracil in DNA either. Uracil is found in RNA, not DNA, and adenine pairs with thymine in DNA, not guanine. C. A → C, T → G is incorrect because adenine does not pair with cytosine, nor does thymine pair with guanine. This would violate the established base pairing rules in both DNA and RNA. D. A → G, T → C is incorrect because adenine does not pair with guanine, and thymine does not pair with cytosine. This would also contradict Watson and Crick's base pairing principles for double-stranded DNA.

choices.text: Matches with RNA transcript that encodes protein

questions.text: True about coding strand of DNA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,C) Plus strand and C. Matches with RNA transcript that encodes protein. The coding strand of DNA is also known as the plus strand because it has the same sequence as the mRNA (except with thymine (T) replaced by uracil (U) in RNA). The coding strand directly carries the genetic information that is used to produce proteins, and its sequence matches the RNA transcript that encodes for a protein. During transcription, the mRNA is synthesized by reading the complementary minus strand (template strand) of DNA, but it mirrors the sequence of the coding (plus) strand. A. Minus strand is incorrect because the minus strand is the template strand for RNA transcription, not the coding strand. It is complementary to the coding strand and is used to generate the mRNA. D. Acts as template for mRNA is incorrect because the coding strand does not serve as the template for mRNA. Instead, the minus strand (template strand) of DNA is used to synthesize the mRNA, while the coding strand has the same sequence as the mRNA.

questions.text: Left handed helix is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Z DNA. Z DNA is a left-handed helix, meaning the strands twist in the opposite direction compared to the more common right-handed helix seen in other forms of DNA. Z DNA has a zigzag backbone structure and is typically formed under specific conditions, such as high salt concentrations or in certain DNA sequences. This form of DNA is less stable than the more common right-handed B DNA but still plays a role in biological processes like gene regulation. A. A DNA is incorrect because A DNA is a right-handed helix. It is a dehydrated form of DNA and is right-handed, with 11 base pairs per turn of the helix. A DNA is generally observed in laboratory conditions with low humidity. B. B DNA is incorrect because B DNA is the most common and biologically relevant form of DNA, and it is a right-handed helix. B DNA is the typical form of DNA found under physiological conditions and is the one most often seen in living organisms. C. C DNA is incorrect because C DNA is another right-handed helical form of DNA, with similar characteristics to B DNA but with a different structural twist. It is not left-handed, making this option incorrect as well.

questions.text: Which form of DNA is predominantly seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) B DNA. B DNA is the most predominant form of DNA under physiological conditions in living organisms. It is a right-handed double helix with 10 base pairs per turn and is the standard form that is found in the vast majority of cellular processes such as replication and transcription. This form is stable and most commonly observed in the natural state of DNA. B. A DNA is incorrect because although A DNA is a right-handed helix, it is found under dehydrated or experimental conditions and is not the predominant form in biological systems. It is more compact and has 11 base pairs per turn, but it does not represent the normal state of DNA in cells. C. Z DNA is incorrect because Z DNA is a left-handed helix and is far less common than B DNA. It forms under specific conditions, such as in sequences with alternating purine-pyrimidine bases, and is not the predominant form in vivo. D. C DNA is incorrect because C DNA, like A DNA, is also a right-handed helix, but it is not the predominant form of DNA in most living cells. It occurs under certain conditions but does not dominate biological DNA structures.

choices.text: Measured by absorbance at 260nm in a spectrophotometer
It occurs when DNA duplex is denatured
Double stranded DNA is more hyperchromic than ssDNA

questions.text: Not true about DNA hyperchromatism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) What is DNA Hyperchromatism? DNA hyperchromicity refers to the increase in absorbance (optical density, OD) at 260 nm when double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) is denatured into single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). This occurs because bases in dsDNA are stacked and hydrogen-bonded, limiting their ability to absorb UV light. When the DNA is denatured (by heat or chemicals), the bases become more exposed, leading to increased UV absorption (hyperchromic effect). Evaluating the Options: A. Measured by absorbance at 260 nm in a spectrophotometer → TRUE Nucleic acids absorb light at 260 nm, and spectrophotometers are used to measure this absorbance. B. It occurs when the DNA duplex is denatured → TRUE Denaturation (heat, pH, or chemical agents) disrupts hydrogen bonds, increasing absorbance. C. It is an increase of absorbance → TRUE The hyperchromic effect results in a significant increase in absorbance at 260 nm when DNA unwinds.

questions.text: Denaturation of DNA breaks
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hydrogen bond. During DNA denaturation, the hydrogen bonds between the complementary base pairs (adenine-thymine and guanine-cytosine) are broken, causing the two strands of the DNA double helix to separate. This is the key process in denaturation, where the double-stranded DNA becomes single-stranded. The covalent bonds, such as phosphodiester bonds and glycosidic bonds, remain intact during denaturation. A. Phosphodiester is incorrect because the phosphodiester bonds are the covalent bonds linking the sugar-phosphate backbone of the DNA. These bonds are not broken during denaturation; instead, they remain intact as the strands separate. B. ?-N Glycosidic bond is incorrect because the glycosidic bond connects the nitrogenous bases to the sugar molecule in the nucleotides, but these bonds are not affected by denaturation. Denaturation involves the breaking of hydrogen bonds, not the glycosidic bonds. D. O-Glycosidic bond is incorrect because this term typically refers to a type of bond in carbohydrates, not in the structure of nucleic acids. In DNA, the relevant bond is the N-glycosidic bond, not O-glycosidic.

questions.text: Concentration of DNA is measured by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absorption at 260 nm

questions.text: Which enzyme recognizes specific Palindromic sequence and cuts within a DNA molecule
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Restriction endonuclease. Restriction endonucleases, or restriction enzymes, are enzymes that recognize specific palindromic DNA sequences and cut within or near these sequences. These enzymes are naturally found in bacteria and serve as a defense mechanism against foreign DNA, such as viral DNA. The cutting action of restriction endonucleases occurs at specific sites within the recognized palindromic sequence, resulting in the fragmentation of the DNA. A. Methylase is incorrect because methylases are enzymes that add methyl groups to specific bases in the DNA, typically at adenine or cytosine residues. They do not cut the DNA but are often involved in protecting the bacterial genome from its own restriction endonucleases by methylating the recognition sites. B. Modified enzyme is incorrect because this is a general term and does not specify an enzyme type that cuts DNA. Modified enzymes may refer to enzymes that have been altered for a specific purpose, but they are not specifically responsible for recognizing palindromic sequences and cutting DNA. D. Exonuclease is incorrect because exonucleases are enzymes that remove nucleotides from the ends of a DNA molecule, rather than cutting within the DNA at specific sequences. Exonucleases typically act on single-stranded DNA or the ends of double-stranded DNA, not at specific recognition sites like restriction endonucleases.

questions.text: In mitochondrial genome, UGA code stands for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tryptophan. In the mitochondrial genome, the codon UGA serves as a stop codon in most organisms, but in mitochondria, it has a special function and codes for the amino acid tryptophan. This is a unique characteristic of the mitochondrial translation system compared to the universal genetic code used in the cytoplasm, where UGA typically functions as a stop codon. A. N-formyl methionine is incorrect because N-formyl methionine (fMet) is the initiating amino acid in mitochondrial protein synthesis, but it is not encoded by UGA. Instead, it is encoded by the codon AUG in the mitochondria. C. Methionine is incorrect because in mitochondria, methionine is encoded by the codon AUG, not UGA. UGA, as mentioned, codes for tryptophan in mitochondrial genomes. D. All of the above is incorrect because UGA does not code for all of these amino acids. Specifically, it does not encode N-formyl methionine or methionine in the mitochondrial genome, only tryptophan.

questions.text: Which type of inheritance occurs in MELAS and NARP
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mitochondrial. MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes) and NARP (Neuropathy, Ataxia, and Retinitis Pigmentosa) are both disorders caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA. These diseases follow mitochondrial inheritance, which means they are passed down exclusively from mother to offspring. This is because mitochondria, and therefore mitochondrial DNA, are inherited maternally. Mitochondrial diseases affect the cells' energy production and can result in a variety of neurological and muscular symptoms. A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) is incorrect because MELAS and NARP are not inherited via autosomal dominant patterns. In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of the mutated gene is required for the trait to be expressed, and the gene is located on one of the non-sex chromosomes. However, these conditions are due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA, not nuclear DNA. B. AR (Autosomal Recessive) is incorrect because MELAS and NARP do not follow an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, where both copies of a gene must be mutated for the disease to manifest. Instead, the inheritance is mitochondrial, and it is passed from mother to offspring regardless of the offspring's gender. C. X-linked is incorrect because MELAS and NARP are not inherited through the X chromosome. X-linked inheritance involves mutations on the X chromosome, and while such disorders can affect males and females differently, MELAS and NARP are linked to mutations in the mitochondrial genome, not the X chromosome.

choices.text: < 20% respiratory chain proteins are coded from mitochondrial DNA

questions.text: Which of the following is true for mtDNA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 20% respiratory chain proteins are coded from mitochondrial DNA mtDNA is a double stranded, circular DNA (like prokaryotic DNA) with 16569 bp and contains 37 genes (22 for mt tRNA, 13 for complex of respiratory chainQ and 2 for rRNA). Total proteins in respiratory chain are 67. (13 encoded by mtDNA and other 54 imported from cytoplasm, encoded by nuclear gene). mtDNA encodes for 13 protein subunits of respiratory chain, so 13/67= 19%. High mutation rate in mtDNA because of exposure to reactive oxygen species, less effective proof reading and absence or very few introns.

questions.text: Euchromatin is the region of DNA which is relatively
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Uncondensed. Euchromatin is the less condensed form of chromatin, typically found in regions of the genome that are actively involved in transcription. It is more accessible to the transcriptional machinery, allowing genes in euchromatin regions to be transcribed more readily. These regions appear lighter under a microscope due to their less compact structure compared to heterochromatin. A. Condensed is incorrect because euchromatin is not condensed. Condensed chromatin refers to heterochromatin, which is tightly packed and often transcriptionally inactive. C. Partially condensed is incorrect because euchromatin is generally considered uncondensed, not partially condensed. The more relaxed structure is necessary for active gene expression. D. Over condensed is incorrect because euchromatin is not over-condensed. Over-condensation is typically associated with inactive regions of DNA, such as heterochromatin, which is tightly packed and less accessible for transcription.

questions.text: Histone has post translational modification by a/e
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glycosylation. Histones are subject to various post-translational modifications that play crucial roles in regulating gene expression and chromatin structure. Glycosylation is one of the rare but known post-translational modifications of histones, where sugar molecules are added to specific residues, which can influence chromatin interaction and function, although it is less commonly discussed compared to other modifications. A. Acylation is incorrect because histones can undergo acylation, such as acetylation, which is a well-known post-translational modification that typically regulates gene expression by loosening the chromatin structure, making it more accessible for transcription. However, acylation is not the best answer in this case compared to glycosylation. B. Methylation is incorrect because while methylation is a very important post-translational modification of histones, particularly in the regulation of gene silencing and chromatin structure, it is not the modification specifically referred to by this question, which focuses on glycosylation. C. Phosphorylation is incorrect because phosphorylation of histones also plays a significant role in regulating chromatin structure and function, especially in processes like DNA repair and cell division. However, phosphorylation is not the modification specified in this particular question.

choices.text: Their amino acid sequence are highly variable among organism
They do not undergo any covalent modification

questions.text: What is true for histones protein
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) They are positively charged proteins. Histones are positively charged proteins due to the abundance of basic amino acids, particularly lysine and arginine. These positive charges enable histones to interact with the negatively charged phosphate groups of DNA, facilitating the wrapping of DNA into nucleosomes and contributing to the formation of chromatin. A. Their amino acid sequences are highly variable among organisms is incorrect because histones are highly conserved across species, particularly the core histones (H2A, H2B, H3, H4). This conservation is critical for their role in DNA packaging and chromatin structure. Variability is relatively low in comparison to other proteins. C. They do not undergo any covalent modification is incorrect because histones undergo various covalent modifications, such as acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, and ubiquitination. These modifications play significant roles in regulating gene expression and chromatin structure, influencing processes like transcription, DNA repair, and cell division. D. All of the above is incorrect because options A and C are false, meaning that not all statements are true for histones.

questions.text: How many base pairs associated with single nucleosome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 146. A single nucleosome consists of approximately 146 base pairs of DNA wrapped around a core of histone proteins. This is the fundamental structural unit of chromatin, where DNA is coiled around histone octamers, helping to package the DNA in the nucleus. A. 73 is incorrect because while DNA wrapped around histones is about 146 base pairs long, 73 base pairs would be too short for a full nucleosome core, and it does not match the standard length of DNA associated with a nucleosome. C. 246 is incorrect because 246 base pairs would refer to a longer length of DNA than what is typically wrapped around a single nucleosome. While some linker DNA may be included in the measurement for chromatin structure, the core DNA around the histones is about 146 base pairs. D. 1460 is incorrect because 1460 base pairs would be much longer than the DNA wrapped around a nucleosome. This number could refer to a larger segment of chromatin that includes multiple nucleosomes, but it is not the length of DNA associated with a single nucleosome.

questions.text: The protein rich in basic amino acids that functions in the packaging of DNA in chromosome, is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Histones. Histones are proteins rich in basic amino acids, such as lysine and arginine, which give them a positive charge. This positive charge enables histones to bind to the negatively charged DNA, facilitating the packaging of DNA into nucleosomes and, subsequently, chromosomes. Histones play a critical role in organizing and compacting DNA within the nucleus, making it more manageable during processes like cell division. A. Collagen is incorrect because collagen is a structural protein that provides strength and elasticity to connective tissues like skin, tendons, and bones. It does not function in DNA packaging or interact directly with chromosomal DNA. C. Fibrinogen is incorrect because fibrinogen is a blood plasma protein involved in clotting. It does not participate in DNA packaging or chromatin structure. D. Hyaluronic acid binding protein is incorrect because hyaluronic acid-binding proteins are involved in binding to hyaluronic acid, a major component of the extracellular matrix. These proteins are not involved in the packaging of DNA into chromosomes.

questions.text: DNA gyrase is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prokaryotic DNA topoisomerase II. DNA gyrase is an essential enzyme in prokaryotes that functions as a type of topoisomerase II. It is responsible for introducing negative supercoils into DNA, which helps alleviate the torsional strain generated during DNA replication and transcription. By doing so, it allows the DNA to remain unwound and accessible for these processes. DNA gyrase also has the ability to "untwist" DNA by breaking and rejoining the DNA strands in a controlled manner. A. Prokaryotic DNA topoisomerase I is incorrect because topoisomerase I primarily works by making transient single-strand cuts to relieve supercoiling, and it does not introduce supercoils like DNA gyrase. DNA gyrase functions more specifically as topoisomerase II, which makes double-strand cuts. C. Eukaryotic DNA topoisomerase I is incorrect because eukaryotic topoisomerase I operates similarly to its prokaryotic counterpart, relieving supercoiling by introducing single-strand cuts. However, DNA gyrase is specific to prokaryotes and has a different function related to supercoiling. D. Eukaryotic DNA topoisomerase II is incorrect because although eukaryotic topoisomerase II has a similar role in relieving supercoiling, DNA gyrase is a prokaryotic enzyme. Eukaryotic cells have their own topoisomerase II, but it is distinct from DNA gyrase in terms of origin and specific mechanisms.

questions.text: Ends of chromosome replicated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Telomerase. Telomerase is an enzyme responsible for maintaining and replicating the ends of chromosomes, known as telomeres. Since the DNA replication machinery cannot fully replicate the very ends of chromosomes, telomerase extends the telomeres by adding repetitive nucleotide sequences to them. This process helps prevent the loss of important genetic information during cell division, ensuring chromosome stability. A. DNA reverse transcriptase is incorrect because although reverse transcriptase is an enzyme that synthesizes DNA from an RNA template (as seen in retroviruses), it is not involved in replicating the ends of chromosomes. Telomerase, which has reverse transcriptase activity, is the enzyme specifically responsible for extending telomeres. B. RNA polymerase is incorrect because RNA polymerase is involved in the synthesis of RNA from a DNA template, not in replicating chromosome ends. It plays a crucial role in transcription but does not have a role in telomere maintenance or replication. D. DNA polymerase is incorrect because while DNA polymerase is involved in replicating the majority of the DNA during cell division, it cannot fully replicate the ends of chromosomes (the telomeres). Telomerase is the enzyme that compensates for this limitation by extending the telomeres.

questions.text: Action of telomerase is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Longevity of cell aging. Telomerase plays a crucial role in counteracting the shortening of telomeres, which occurs with each cell division. By adding repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes, telomerase helps maintain chromosomal integrity and prevents premature cell aging. In many somatic cells, telomerase activity is low or absent, leading to progressive telomere shortening and cellular senescence. However, in stem cells, germ cells, and certain cancer cells, telomerase is active, allowing for prolonged cell division and longevity. A. DNA repair is incorrect because telomerase does not function as a DNA repair enzyme. While it maintains chromosome stability by elongating telomeres, it does not repair damaged DNA strands or correct mutations. C. Breakdown of telomere is incorrect because telomerase does the opposite—it extends and maintains telomeres rather than breaking them down. Telomere shortening occurs naturally in most somatic cells due to the end-replication problem, but telomerase counteracts this process in specific cell types. D. None is incorrect because telomerase has a well-defined role in extending cellular lifespan by maintaining telomere length, which directly impacts aging and cell longevity.
